dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Trump's proposed spending plan, they're saying it's urgently needed based on this new GDP and employment surge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Trump's proposed spending plan, they're saying it's urgently needed based on this new G D P and employment surge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By contrast, Bidens proposed spending plan is urgently needed. Recently released data show a slowdown in Americas recovery both in terms of GDP and employment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah but wait, the article points out there's scant evidence it'll actually stimulate the economy, right? Like, the growth might generate negligible tax revenues.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah but wait, the article points out there's scant evidence it'll actually stimulate the economy, right? Like, the growth might generate negligible tax revenues.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There is overwhelming evidence that the recovery package will provide enormous stimulus to the economy, and that economic growth will generate substantial tax revenues, not just for the federal government but also for the states and municipalities that are now starved of the funds they need to provide essential services.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, and it's only for the federal government—states and municipalities get left out. And then they bring up this whole deflation warning from supporters.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, and it's only for the federal government-states and municipalities get left out. And then they bring up this whole deflation warning from supporters.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Opponents of the Biden plan also disingenuously warn against inflation that lurking bogeyman that is more fantasy than real threat nowadays. ...economic growth will generate substantial tax revenues, not just for the federal government but also for the states and municipalities that are now starved of the funds they need to provide essential services.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which the piece calls disingenuous! But then it admits, uh, if deflation does hit, the US has limited tools to fight it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which the piece calls disingenuous! But then it admits, uh, if deflation does hit, the U S has limited tools to fight it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But if inflation does emerge, the US has ample monetary and fiscal tools at the ready.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And they mention wages might be rising dramatically across sectors, which is interesting. But then it swings back to how a large recovery package could do minimal damage, maybe even short-term.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they mention wages might be rising dramatically across sectors, which is interesting. But then it swings back to how a large recovery package could do minimal damage, maybe even short-term.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Indeed, some data suggest that wages may be falling in parts of the economy. There is a real risk that not passing a large recovery package will do enormous, and possibly long-lasting, damage.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Because good economic performance reduces anxiety, which boosts consumption and investment. It's like an upward spiral.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Because good economic performance reduces anxiety, which boosts consumption and investment. It's like an upward spiral.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This is because poor economic performance heightens economic anxiety (compounding the anxiety induced by the pandemic itself), leading to a downward spiral in which precautionary behavior lowers consumption and investment, further weakening the economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then they drop this bombshell—firms that thrived during the pandemic might "un-thrive" themselves after COVID is under control. What does that even mean?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then they drop this bombshell-firms that thrived during the pandemic might un-thrive themselves after COVID is under control. What does that even mean?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After all, firms that have gone bankrupt in the pandemic will not un-bankrupt themselves when COVID-19 is brought under control.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I think it means some businesses that did well in the pandemic economy might struggle when things normalize. But globally, the article says the pandemic's scope might actually help because it strengthens demand for US exports.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I think it means some businesses that did well in the pandemic economy might struggle when things normalize. But globally, the article says the pandemic's scope might actually help because it strengthens demand for U S exports.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The fact that COVID-19 is a pandemic global in scope makes matters worse. While the best available data suggests that many developing countries and emerging markets have not been hit as badly as people feared they would be a year ago, the global economys unprecedented slowdown implies softening demand for US exports.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And they bring up China's role—how its recovery was stronger post-2008, and now it's letting trade surpluses contract to help global growth.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they bring up China's role-how its recovery was stronger postminus two thousand eight, and now it's letting trade surpluses contract to help global growth.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: China is also now allowing its trade surpluses to grow, providing less impetus to global growth.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But back to the Trump plan—it doesn't incorporate key features, so it could yield large losses. They argue funds should go to fighting the pandemic and helping schools and local services.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But back to the Trump plan-it doesn't incorporate key features, so it could yield large losses. They argue funds should go to fighting the pandemic and helping schools and local services.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Because the Biden plan incorporates the key features of what must be done, it promises to yield large returns. A first priority is to ensure that funds are available to fight the pandemic, to enable children to return to school, and to allow states and localities to continue to provide the health, education, and other services that people depend on.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And they claim extending unemployment insurance might actually hurt the vulnerable by decreasing spending? That feels counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they claim extending unemployment insurance might actually hurt the vulnerable by decreasing spending? That feels counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Extending unemployment insurance will not only help the vulnerable. By providing reassurance, it will lead to an increase in spending, with economy-wide benefits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and eviction moratoriums and aid to low-income families could discourage spending too. Plus, the rich have a low propensity to consume, so targeting top incomes might sink the economy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and eviction moratoriums and aid to low-income families could discourage spending too. Plus, the rich have a low propensity to consume, so targeting top incomes might sink the economy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The moratorium on evictions through March 31 and assistance to low-income families will also encourage spending. More generally, it is well established that the poor have a high propensity to consume, so a package directed at increasing incomes at the bottom (including an increase in the minimum wage, child credits, and the earned income tax credit) will help revive the economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Then they contrast it with Biden's small business programs, which had issues—too much money went to very small businesses, and there were administrative problems.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Then they contrast it with Biden's small business programs, which had issues-too much money went to very small businesses, and there were administrative problems.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Under President Donald Trump, the programs that focused on small businesses were not as effective as they could or should have been partly because too much of the money went to businesses that were not really small, and partly because of a rash of administrative problems.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And if those aren't fixed, expanding aid might hurt short-term and put the economy in bad stead as the pandemic wanes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And if those aren't fixed, expanding aid might hurt short-term and put the economy in bad stead as the pandemic wanes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If so, expanding aid to businesses will not only help in the short run, but will also put the economy in good stead as the pandemic wanes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So economists will argue about the details, but the article's bottom line is that small amounts of money aren't needed, and opposing support is heartless and short-sighted.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So economists will argue about the details, but the article's bottom line is that small amounts of money aren't needed, and opposing support is heartless and short-sighted.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But where there should be no disagreement is that large amounts of money are needed urgently, and that opposition to it is both heartless and dangerously short-sighted.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty strong stance. Makes you think about how complex recovery really is.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty strong stance. Makes you think about how complex recovery really is.

artist_script:
HostA: Trump's proposed spending plan, they're saying it's urgently needed based on this new GDP and employment surge.
HostB: Yeah but wait, the article points out there's scant evidence it'll actually stimulate the economy, right? Like, the growth might generate negligible tax revenues.
HostA: Exactly, and it’s only for the federal government—states and municipalities get left out. And then they bring up this whole deflation warning from supporters.
HostB: Which the piece calls disingenuous! But then it admits, uh, if deflation does hit, the US has limited tools to fight it.
HostA: And they mention wages might be rising dramatically across sectors, which is interesting. But then it swings back to how a large recovery package could do minimal damage, maybe even short-term.
HostB: Because good economic performance reduces anxiety, which boosts consumption and investment. It’s like an upward spiral.
HostA: But then they drop this bombshell—firms that thrived during the pandemic might "un-thrive" themselves after COVID is under control. What does that even mean?
HostB: I think it means some businesses that did well in the pandemic economy might struggle when things normalize. But globally, the article says the pandemic's scope might actually help because it strengthens demand for US exports.
HostA: And they bring up China’s role—how its recovery was stronger post-2008, and now it's letting trade surpluses contract to help global growth.
HostB: But back to the Trump plan—it doesn’t incorporate key features, so it could yield large losses. They argue funds should go to fighting the pandemic and helping schools and local services.
HostA: And they claim extending unemployment insurance might actually hurt the vulnerable by decreasing spending? That feels counterintuitive.
HostB: Right, and eviction moratoriums and aid to low-income families could discourage spending too. Plus, the rich have a low propensity to consume, so targeting top incomes might sink the economy.
HostA: Then they contrast it with Biden’s small business programs, which had issues—too much money went to very small businesses, and there were administrative problems.
HostB: And if those aren’t fixed, expanding aid might hurt short-term and put the economy in bad stead as the pandemic wanes.
HostA: So economists will argue about the details, but the article’s bottom line is that small amounts of money aren’t needed, and opposing support is heartless and short-sighted.
HostB: Pretty strong stance. Makes you think about how complex recovery really is.
